title: How has Shen suddenly become popular?
body:
If I were to ask, like, two weeks ago, certainly anyone would reply that the reason why Shen is not popular is because he doesn't have a lot to offer as a tank, his shield scales with AP instead of health, and he doesn't have the same level of teamfighting potential as other tanks.

Yet he now sees a lot of popularity as a top laner, and even as support.

Why?

People don't understand that there is a reason why pro picked X champion, and that X champion may not work on all team comps, or situations.

His biggest issue in the past was the fact that he has a minuscule hit box on his taunt dash, and that is is only good way to regain energy and also costs almost all his energy to use. This led to Shen being a champion who was basically useless if he didn't hit his dash on at least 2 people. The reason he is better now is because they buffed a couple of his energy costs so you can actually do a full rotation of abilities (You could barely do a rotation before, and if you missed your dash you wouldn't be able to use more than one other spell) now you can do a full rotation whether or not you land your taunt.

2 very simple and desperately needed buffs: 

MR per level and shadow dash's energy cost buff (now it's 100/95/90/85/80 instead of 100 flat)

That is the *only thing that has changed since before he started showing up everywhere.

because he got some really beneficial buffs a few patches ago.

Shen allows for a free farm lane by his opponents, meaning the best goal is to put a hard scaling champion (Jax was favorable in previous seasons) against him and trying to survive until late game.

Not too many teams are playing hard scaling top laners, Ryze being the most favored of them with Jax being played by only a few (Werlyb)

Shen's goal was to win the mid game and then split push heavily in the late game.

------

Playing with and against a Shen is different than *ANY OTHER* top laner.  This means teams have to get used to playing with a Shen.  Shen is difficult to practice in solo-que because of the lack of communication for Shen ports so once Shen was fixed, teams had to decide if he was worth practicing, and then actually practicing him.

With the buffs which are huge for him, Shen can actually taunt more than once reliably in a fight, and has much better damage and shield uptime thanks to the passive increase.  This means his resiliency is WAY better in a team fight then before.

Poke compositions are huge currently, and teams who aren't practiced against a Shen team can find themselves falling behind in the mid-game due to his near permanent map pressure between his ultimate and teleport.  Additionally, the main strategy against a poke composition is to flank, Shen offers an easy way to get a dive/flank buddy in.  (Another reason we've seen some Nocturne).

The reason Shen is seeing more play top, aside from the aforementioned LCS spotlight and buffs, is the introduction of the Bami's Cinder item. Shen has always required Sunfire Cape to farm and split push effectively in the top lane, and now he gets the passive even earlier than he did before, which gives him more gold and thus better item scaling into the mid game. It's true that Bami's Cinder has been out for a while, but now that people are taking Shen top more because of the LCS, they're building this item they never had a chance to build on him in previous seasons and seeing a much better lane phase as a result.
